text: In Step 2, you learned how to build an interactive web app using Shiny. Let’s assume that your coworkers are interested in learning about it and assume that you are helping them. Create a lecture note that you can use to teach the person. This will become part of the website under “Essay on Shiny Apps.”

title: Essay on Shiny Apps
text:
What Is Shiny?
Shiny is an R package developed by Posit (formerly RStudio) that makes it simple to build interactive web applications. It’s a powerful tool for data analysts and scientists who want to share results in a more engaging, hands-on way.
Whether you’re building a data exploration tool, a dashboard for KPIs, or a simulation model, Shiny helps you move from reporting data to engaging users with it.

title: Essay on Shiny Apps
section: How a Shiny App Is Structured
text:
How a Shiny App Is Structured
Shiny apps are built around three core components:

1. UI (User Interface)
This is what your users see — the layout, buttons, sliders, plots, and tables. You design the interface using functions like fluidPage(), sidebarLayout(), and mainPanel().


2. Server Function
This is where the logic happens. The server function takes the user’s input and tells the app what to do with it — like filtering a dataset or updating a graph.


3. shinyApp()
This wraps everything together and launches the app in a browser.

title: Essay on Shinylive
text: In Step 3, you learned about serverless Shiny Apps with “Shinylive.” What is Shinylive? Assume that you are also explaining it to your coworkers. How does it differ from the traditional Shiny app introduced in Step 2? What are the pros and cons of Shinylive in comparison with Shiny Apps? This lecture note will become your “Essay on Shiny Live” part of the website.

title: Essay on Shinylive
text:
Key Differences








Feature
Traditional Shiny
Shinylive




Hosting
Needs R server
Runs in browser (serverless)


Setup
Moderate
Very simple


Package Support
Full R packages
Limited to browser-safe packages


Use Cases
Dashboards, internal apps
Demos, teaching, lightweight tools

title: Essay on Shinylive
text:
Pros and Cons
Pros:

No server or hosting costs
Easy deployment (works with static sites)
Great for small apps, education, and demos

Cons:

Limited package support
No access to external data or files
Not ideal for large or complex apps

title: Essay on Shinylive
text:
Final Thoughts
Shinylive is best for simple, shareable apps. Think quick prototypes, interactive lectures, or public demos. For more complex apps with real-time data or heavier processing, traditional Shiny will still be the better tool to use.

title: Vehicle Performance Dashboard
text:
As you watch videos on Quarto Dashboard in Step 1, follow along with the data of your choice and create a dashboard you can add to your website.



Vehicle Performance Dashboard
This interactive dashboard uses the built-in mtcars dataset to explore the relationship between weight, miles per gallon (MPG), and engine characteristics.

library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)


Attaching package: 'plotly'


The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2':

    last_plot


The following object is masked from 'package:stats':

    filter


The following object is masked from 'package:graphics':

    layout

# Create a scatter plot
p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = as.factor(cyl), text = rownames(mtcars))) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "Fuel Efficiency vs. Vehicle Weight",
    x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    y = "Miles per Gallon",
    color = "Cylinders"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

# Convert to interactive plot
ggplotly(p, tooltip = "text")
